The sun has risen in New York on this 20th Anniversary of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks and the emotions remain raw, memories vivid and love of country unbreakable.

May God continue to be with the families, friends, and loved ones of those who lost their lives on that tragic day and in the many years that followed.

And may we #neverforget.
And finally, we will #neverforget the promise we made to take care of all those still suffering from 9/11 related illnesses.

We will #neverforget the over 7,000 U.S. troops killed in the post-9/11 conflicts in the Middle East and around the world. Nor will we forget the over 30,000 veterans who have taken their own lives since September 11, 2001.
We will #neverforget the bravery of those patriots on United Flight 93, who banded together to take down the hijackers before they could reach their target.

We will #neverforget the brave firefighters & police officers running up the stairs of the World Trade Center, willing to risk their own lives so others may live.

We will never forget the first responders & civilians, working day & night at Ground Zero, searching for survivors.

10/ Today I‚Äôm grieving for all the families who lost loved ones twenty years ago today. And I‚Äôm also remembering the day that set in motion the work of millions of Americans chose, in the wake of that terrible day, to try to make their country better and safer.

9/ I was deeply uncomfortable about the way in which America over militarized our response to 9/11. But I didn‚Äôt want America to withdraw from the world. So I set about the work of properly learning the lessons of Iraq and Afghanistan, and course correcting U.S. foreign policy.

8/ People always ask me why I spend so much time working on foreign policy and national security issues. 

It all comes back to 9/11. My generation was formed by it. We are defined by it. The choices we have made since then are derivative of it.

7/ But I was a state legislator with no role to play in the biggest issue that affected my generation. I grew frustrated. 

So in early 2005, just over 3 years after 9/11, I decided to make a long shot race for Congress. There I could make a difference I thought.

6/ Within two years America was at war in two far off nations.

I knew Afghanistan was the right war, but as my friends were being sent to fight a war of choice in Iraq, I became more and more worried we had made a costly error as a nation.

5/ The national conversation naturally launched into talk of retribution. 

That night I watched with my parents as Bush declared ‚ÄúWe will make no distinction between the terrorists who committed these acts and those that harbored them.‚Äù

This made perfect sense to me.

4/ I was glued to the TV the rest of the morning, making occasional calls to see if I could connect with friends in the city. 

Eventually I headed to my parents house in Wethersfield where my parents had cable. We would learn that we lost 3 family friends who were in the towers.

3/ As a poor state legislator who spent my entire salary on law school tuition, I didn‚Äôt own a proper television or have cable back then. So I pulled out a tiny black and white set and found the antenna only picked up one channel - WTNH.

2/ I was at a meeting at Southington High School, just around the corner from my one bedroom apartment. I watched the initial reports of a plane crash on the small televisions in the school‚Äôs library. It looked like an accident at first, and I headed back home.
1/ I was 27 on September 11, 2001. A second term state legislator. For people like me, in their formative stage of public service in 2001, 9/11 was definitional. It charted our course.

As we mark this solemn anniversary, I hope that we can all summon the energy to restore that sense of togetherness, patriotism, and common purpose we felt as Americans after September 11 ‚Äì not just today, but every day.

We have had successes ‚Äì Osama Bin Laden is dead, attempted terrorist attacks have been thwarted, and the world is a safer place with increased international cooperation ‚Äì but those victories serve as no consolation to those who have lost a child, a spouse, a parent, or a friend.

We will never forget what happened on September 11. We will never forget those who lost their lives and were injured in Afghanistan and Iraq, and we will never forget the sacrifices that their families have made in the ensuing years.

As we commemorate this important anniversary, we must rekindle this sense of service and commitment to strengthening our nation that all shared in the aftermath of 9/11 for years and decades to come.

#NeverForget

But we must also remember how we mobilized as a nation and came together as one after September 11, and we must take that memory and move forward to see how we can work together to solve the problems we face both domestically and internationally.

We remember the many heroes of that day‚Äîthe brave people who risked life and limb to help those in need, many of whom are still feeling the health consequences today. These first responders never cowered in their call to public service, and were joined by perfect strangers.
The twentieth year of U.S. forces coming home with injuries that will impact them and their families for the rest of their lives.
And, sadly, as we saw just two weeks ago, it is the twentieth year of brave Americans making the ultimate sacrifice for our nation as a result of the War on Terror.

Today is the 20th anniversary of the #September11 terrorist attacks.

As each year and each decade passes, we have marked this day as a time for remembrance. We remember those we lost, and their families and loved ones. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_BBUpQXMAgb2O1.jpg
It‚Äôs also the twentieth year of first responders suffering from medical issues, the result of their courageously rushing through the ash and smoke to Ground Zero to save lives.

Today also marks the start of the twentieth year of missed birthdays for the children who never had the chance to get to know their parent, the twentieth year of missed wedding anniversaries, the twentieth year of mourning.
But today is not just the 20th anniversary of a cowardly attack on our nation.
We remember the horror we felt as we heard the news on that quiet Tuesday morning ‚Äì I was in my car on my way to the office when I heard it on the radio.
We remember the images of falling towers, a smoldering Pentagon, and the field in Shanksville where courageous passengers and crew died as heroes.
We remember the more than 6,000 injured.
We remember the 2,977 innocent lives lost.
Today we remember.

So what I am asking is that today, as you reflect on where you were on 9/11, you remember the unity felt in the days and weeks after that terrible day. 

As you go into next week, be kind to your fellow Americans. Be helpful. Honor those we lost 20 years ago today with unity.
It saddens me that we are a nation so divided now. We must embody the spirit of kindness and helpfulness without going through another tragedy to pull us together.
But more than the heartbreak & sadness, I was moved by the unity and kindness people displayed for one another. Strangers helping strangers. All of America rooting for New York & DC & Pennsylvania.

I knew it would be a difficult scene, but nothing can prepare you for that kind of carnage, the smoke rising from the wreckage or witnessing the despair of families still searching and hoping to find their loved ones.

Like everyone else, I was terrified & heartbroken by this tragedy. I grieved for the people who never came home from work at the towers & the Pentagon, or their flight. 

I went to New York as soon as we could. I needed to see it for myself. I needed to see my friends & family.

Whenever big, lifechanging events happen, we remember where we were or what we were doing that day. 

Illinois is my home now, but I'm a native New Yorker. My family & best friends still live there. They're the people I was thinking of when I heard the terrible news 20 years ago.
